Kenrick loves Xharah.
     
The concept of love, however, is subject to debate. Some deny the existence of love, calling it a recently invented abstraction. Moreover, approximately 13 percent of cultures reportedly have no word for love.<ref>{{cite book | author=Ackerman, Diane | title=A Natural History of Love | publisher=Vintage Books | year=1994 | id=ISBN 0679761837}}</ref> Others maintain that love exists but is undefinable; being a quantity which is [[spirituality|spiritual]], [[metaphysical]], or [[philosophical]] in nature, etc. Perhaps due to its emotional primacy, love is one of the most common themes in art.
 
The concept of love, however, is subject to debate. Some deny the existence of love, calling it a recently invented abstraction. Moreover, approximately 13 percent of cultures reportedly have no word for love.<ref>{{cite book | author=Ackerman, Diane | title=A Natural History of Love | publisher=Vintage Books | year=1994 | id=ISBN 0679761837}}</ref> Others maintain that love exists but is undefinable; being a quantity which is [[spirituality|spiritual]], [[metaphysical]], or [[philosophical]] in nature, etc. Perhaps due to its emotional primacy, love is one of the most common themes in art.
